INTRODUCTION

2.
UNTAET,  in  consultation  with  the  East  Timor  Transitional  Administration  (ETTA),  the
National Council of East Timor, and members of East Timor's civil society, has asked the Asian
Development Bank (ADB), through the TFET, to provide further assistance in rehabilitating and
restoring  the  damaged  and  inadequate  water  supply  and  sanitation  infrastructure  throughout
East  Timor,  and  concurrently  to  reestablish  the  human  and  institutional  capacity  needed  to
manage,  operate,  and  maintain  the  facilities.  An  ADB  Mission2  prepared  a  Project  with
authorized  UNTAET/ETTA  representatives.  The  agreements  reached  were  confirmed  in  a
memorandum  of  understanding.  The  Project  was  prepared  in  accordance  with  the  Joint
Management  Arrangements  for  the  Trust  Fund  for  East  Timor.3  The  TFET  does  not  include
ADB's own resources.

A. 

Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Description

III. 

BACKGROUND

The  water  supply  and  sanitation  (WS&S)  sector  status  is  summarized  in  the  following

3.
paragraphs. Additional details are in Appendix 2.

1. 

Current Status

a. 

Institutional Arrangements

4.
The  Water  and  Sanitation  Service  (WSS)  of  UNTAET  has  been  established  and  is
operating. WSS now has staff in all districts, is managing 13 public water supply systems in Dili
and the other district capitals, and through the first Water Supply and Sanitation Rehabilitation
Project  (WSSRP-1)  and  other  external  support  has  commenced 
the  essential  policy
development and institutional capacity building required to develop its capacity to deliver WS&S
services.  The  strategic  plan  for  WSS  (Appendix  3)  requires  WSS  to  assume  broad
responsibilities  for  the  delivery  of  WS&S  services  including  water  policy/water  resource
management, water supply, sanitation, solid waste, and drainage. Under the pre-independence
administration,  these  functions  were  fragmented  across  several  ministries  and  levels  of
government.

5.
WSS  is  a  newly  formed  agency,  which  is  just  developing  its  staff,  institutional
infrastructure,  policies  and  legislation,  and  operational  and  management  systems.  WSS
requires significant capacity building. Sector rehabilitation activities are being undertaken in an

b. 

Water Supply

6.
Under  the  pre-independence  administration,  the  quality  of  the  public  water  supply
systems  was  problematic  with  many  of  them  poorly  planned,  designed,  and  operated.  Typical
deficiencies  were  low  service  coverage,  poor  maintenance,  high  levels  of  unaccounted-for
water, intermittent supply, inappropriate treatment systems, poor water quality particularly from
surface  water  sources  during  the  wet  season,  and  frequent  failure  due  to  flood  and  landslide
damage to transmission pipelines. Service coverage4 in the piped systems was low (39 percent
in  district  capitals  and  29  percent  in  subdistrict  towns).  Private  shallow  wells  were  extensively
used in the urban areas in Dili and other towns.

Villages  and  rural  areas  not  served  by  the  public  water  supply  systems  had  extensive
7.
community-owned  and  -operated  piped  systems.  Some  of  these  received  water  from  public
systems  and  others  sourced  water  from  small  springs  or  streams.  Shallow  wells  were  also
extensively used in villages and rural areas, especially those near the sea or on river plains. It
was estimated that 48 percent of the total population of East Timor had access to safe water.5

8.
A  summary  of  key  impacts  of  the  violence  on  water  supply  follows.  (i)  The  institutions
responsible  for  water  supply  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  ceased  to  exist  after  the
Indonesian withdrawal. While many of the technical and administrative support staff were East
Timorese,  the  majority  of  the  management  and  professional  staff  of  the  PDAM/BPAMs  (local
government  water  enterprise/district  water  board)  were  Indonesians  whose  departure  had
significant implications for human resource capacity. Many technical staff from the former water
enterprises have assisted in the process of restoring supplies. (ii) The institutional infrastructure
including  buildings  and  other  assets,  technical  and  financial  records,  vehicles,  tools,  and
equipment were either stolen or destroyed. (iii) Consumer connections were generally destroyed
with  the  widespread  destruction  of  the  houses  that  they  served.  (iv)  The  large  numbers  of
displaced  persons  that  have  moved  into  the  urban  areas,  particularly  in  Dili,  caused  further
damage  and physical damage  to pipes as they attempt to access water supply through  illegal
connection.  (v)  Damage  to  major  installations,  such  as  treatment  plants,  was  limited.  Some
bores  were  destroyed  and  pumps  and/or  electrical  switchboards  removed.  In  some  instances,
bore  casings  were  filled  with  rocks.  (vi)  Power  supplies  were  damaged,  significantly  affecting
pumped  systems,  especially  in  the  early  period  after  the  Indonesian  withdrawal.  Anecdotal
information  indicates  that  damage  to  rural  supplies  was  not  extensive.  However,  there  were
pockets of damage that showed contamination of sources such as shallow wells.

Since the destruction in September 1999, there has been significant progress with both

c. 

Sanitation

11.
Sanitation  coverage  before  independence  was  estimated  at  38  percent  (footnote  5).
Damage  to  sanitation  facilities  occurred  as  houses  were  destroyed.  In  addition,  facilities  to
maintain and desludge septic tanks were destroyed. As a consequence, access to higher order
sanitation systems in the urban areas decreased. The damage to water supplies also impacted
on  water  availability  and  use  for  sanitation.  Anecdotal  evidence  indicates  limited  impact  on
sanitation systems in rural areas. Some facilities have been implemented, particularly in Dili, to
accommodate  the  additional  demands  created  by  the  influx  of  UNTAET  and  peacekeeping
forces (PKF) personnel.

12. While  the  initial  emergency  phase  rehabilitation  activities  focused  on  water  supply,
donors  and  NGOs  are  now  expanding  their  activities  to  incorporate  integrated  programs  for
WS&S,  which  include  community  education  and  hygiene  promotion  aimed  at  improving
environmental  sanitation  through  community  participatory  approaches.  Similar  activities  are
being  undertaken  under  WSSRP-1  through  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  in  Dili  and
several district towns.

d. 

Solid Waste

13.
Before  independence,  most  towns  had  a  solid  waste  collection  system  in  which  waste
was  deposited  in  strategically  located  collection  boxes.  The  capacity  of  the  collection  systems
was grossly inadequate and wastes were indiscriminately dumped in drains and on roadsides.
The  operation  of  solid  waste  disposal  sites  was  questionable.  Significant  quantities  of  waste
were  disposed  of  by  burning.  There  was  no  solid  waste  management  system  in  Dili  after  the
Indonesian withdrawal. Previous systems involved both community and institutional participation
in solid waste collection, cartage and disposal. But equipment (handcarts and trucks) used for
collection  and  transport  were  either  destroyed,  diverted  to  other  uses,  or  removed.  The
provincial sanitation office (Dinas Kebersihan) within the former Dili city administration no longer
exists. Markets were destroyed, and solid waste is generated from informal markets that have
established on roadsides. The equipment previously used in the solid waste collection systems
in  other  district  towns  was  either  destroyed  or  removed.  The  community  and  institutional
systems for collection and disposal are no longer operating.

14.
The large expatriate presence has a significant impact on the generation of solid waste–
bottled water containers, soft drinks and beer cans–and a general increase in the importation of
consumer goods. These problems are particularly apparent in Dili. The general destruction has
created significant additional quantities of solid waste including building rubble, roofing material,
car bodies etc. Much of this still litters Dili streets for lack of capacity to collect and dispose of it.

15.
Initial  solid  waste  management  activities  were  undertaken  through  the  Community
Empowerment  and  Local  Governance  Project  (CEP)  and  other  programs  mainly  in  Dili.
WSSRP-1  provides  support  in  critical  areas  such  as  markets  and  in  the  cleanup  of  large
quantities of waste generated by the postconsultation destruction. Portugal has funded studies

 4

on  solid  waste  management  in  Dili  and  the  districts,  but  does  not  propose  to  fund  the
implementation of recommended proposals.

e. 

Drainage

16.
Except  in Dili, the drainage  systems in most towns comprise a network of minor street
drains and are not of major significance. In problem areas, the drains are smelly because of the
discharge of septic tank effluent and/or gray water, exacerbated by solid waste deposited in the
drains and lack of regular maintenance. Occasional flooding occurs during the wet season. Dili
has  a  major  drainage  system  constructed  originally  during  the  Portuguese  period  and
subsequently extended during the Indonesian period. The system has been poorly maintained
and  badly  neglected  for  many  years.  Deficiencies  include  poorly  designed  and  poorly
constructed  drains  (frequently  lacks  level  control),  significant  solid  waste  and  silt  deposition
reducing  drain  cross-section,  broken  roadside  entry  pits,  and  broken  or  missing  drain  covers.
The drains provide breeding grounds for vermin and insects and are a significant health hazard.
Lack  of  maintenance  combined  with  poor  design  and  construction  causes  flooding  during  the
wet season. A master plan for Dili drainage was prepared in 1995 but was not implemented.

17.
The drainage systems sustained no obvious damage during the violence, but they had
gradually  deteriorated  even  before  the  Indonesian  withdrawal  because  of  lack  of  maintenance
and increasing use of the drains as receiving areas for solid waste including building rubble. No
major  systematic  work  has  been  undertaken  on  Dili  drainage.  Disposing  solid  waste  including
general garbage and building waste into drains continues, reducing the capacity of the drains to
handle flood flows. Sediment deposition and agricultural activities in some major drains are also
of concern.

2.

Indonesian administration. Nevertheless substantial rehabilitation investment is still required and
capacity  building  is  needed.  Donor  interest  in  the  sector  is  high.  WSSRP-1  has  significantly
contributed to overall sector development.

1. 

General Assessment

East Timor's massive political, economic, and social upheaval in the period from August
46.
1999 to September 1999 exacerbated the previously high poverty levels. By mid-2000, security
was being restored. Farming is the primary occupation of 85 percent of household heads. Cash
incomes are almost nonexistent among the rural population. The poor are characterized by lack
of education and low literacy, high dependency burdens, and a dependence on agriculture.

Using  survey  data  (in  the  ADB-funded  report,  East  Timor  Rapid  Assessment  of
47.
Economic  and  Social  Conditions,  2000)  as  the  basis  for  estimating  poverty  from  1999  to  mid-
2000, the head count index has climbed significantly, reaching around 75 percent. Prior to this,
the incidence of poverty based on the official Indonesian poverty line fell from around 37 percent
in 1993 to around 25 percent in 1997, but from 1997 to 1999 it climbed back to 37 percent due
to  the  financial  crisis  and  political  upheaval.  Prior  to  1998,  the  average  income  of  the  poor
(those below the poverty line) was around 2 percent less than the poverty line. From 1998, this
has steadily increased to about 7 percent in the first half of 2000.

49.
Many governance challenges face the new nation of East Timor. Democratic processes
are  being  introduced.  Self-government  is  a  relatively  new  and  emerging  concept.  The
challenges will be to rebuild trust as a first step to participating in government, especially at the
local level, and to ensure as much local participation in government administration as possible.
A very important requirement of good governance is the skills base to provide the basic services
of  government.  Basic  education,  preventive  health  Care,  family  planning,  and  improved
agricultural  production  are  the  priority  areas  for  investment  and  capacity  building.  Important
infrastructure  is  also  needed  to  facilitate  the  delivery  of  education  and  health  services,  and  to
stimulate commercial activity, especially in the agriculture sector. The reconstruction of schools
and health clinics and their staffing needs are also priorities. The speedy reconstruction of land
transport infrastructure is critical to pro-poor economic development.

50.
Education indicators are generally poor. The last officially recorded literacy rates in 1986
were 51 percent on a national basis and 64 percent among adults. Evidence suggests a distinct
gender bias in education enrollment. For example, in 1998, 52 percent of females over 10 years
of  age  had  never  been  to  school.  Postprimary  education  is  still  disrupted,  and  literacy  among
the rural poor is less than 50 percent.

damaged,  and  130  of  160  physicians  were  reported  to  have  departed  by  mid-2000.  Existing
services in rural communities are extremely limited. However, emergency services are provided
by  NGOs  and  donors.  Prior  to  1999,  life  expectancy  was  around  55-58  years.  Infant  mortality
was  moderately  high  at  85  deaths  per  1,000  births,  and  only  37  percent  of  all  births  were
attended by medical staff. The under-five mortality rate was moderately high at 124 deaths per
1,000 births, and immunization rates varied from 60 to 90 percent. Only 25 percent of villages
had a health clinic, and the average distance to a hospital was 75 kilometers.

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

General

The  Project  will  have  a  positive  social  impact  on  the  East  Timorese  population,
96.
particularly  the  poor.  It  will  provide  safe  water  and  sanitation  to  a  large  part  of  the  population.
Ready  access  to  safe  WS&S  services  will  have  significant  long-term  benefits  by  reducing
waterborne  diseases  including  diarrhea,  dysentery,  malaria,  and  skin  diseases.  It  will  also
contribute  to  human  capital  development  and  reduce  poverty  by  putting  labor,  i.e.,  fetching
water,  to  more  productive  uses.  The  Project  will  maximize  the  use  of  local  contractors  in  its
repair  and  rehabilitation  works,  thereby  creating  jobs  at  the  local  level.  It  will  help  to  develop
sector policies and institutional frameworks in which WS&S services are delivered so that they
take account of the needs of the poor.

97.
Following the complete destruction of all water-related infrastructure, it can be assumed
that  the  net  economic  benefits  will  be  positive,  especially  in  the  urban  areas  where  tariff
schemes  will  eventually  be  introduced.  In  the  rural  areas,  freeing  labor  for  more  productive
economic  uses  and  reducing  health-related  costs  are  expected  to  result  in  the  project's  being
net economically positive.

A key lesson is that in all aspects of WS&S project design, construction, operation, and
98.
maintenance,  the  focus  must  be  on  striving  for  sustainable  solutions.  Experience  in  many
countries over many years has shown that the traditional least-cost approach to planning water
supply projects is inadequate to achieve sustainable resource use efficiency. What is required is
an  approach  that  integrates  both  supply-  and  demand-side  concerns,  and  accounts  for  non-
market  costs  and  benefits.  The  extent  to  which  benefits  from  water  supply  are  likely  to  be
sustained will depend on greater recognition of the role that prices can play in managing water
demand,  expanding  supply,  and  conserving  the  environment.  WSSRP-1  is  addressing  the
establishment  of,  and  improvement  in,  tariff  levels  and  structures  and  further  support  will  be
provided  for  implementation  under  the  proposed  Project.  The  improvement  will  ensure

differential  tariff  regimes  for  different  customer  segments,  some  degree  of  cost  recovery,  and
sustainability of services.

Environmental Aspects

99.
The  Project  is  in  environmental  category  B.  An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)
was conducted in accordance with ADB's Environmental Assessment Requirements (Appendix
9).

The  Project  will  involve  only  minor  construction;  as  such,  transient  environmental
100.
disturbances  normally  experienced  during  construction  will  be 
insignificant.  Typical
environmental disturbances related to water supply and sanitation will include minor excavations
to replace or install pipes and fittings and repair drains; temporary road and street closures to
allow pipe and drain construction activity; minor clearing along short lengths of existing pipeline
routes  to  allow  repairs  and  rehabilitation;  clearing  of  small  areas  (up  to  20  square  meters)  to
give construction equipment and vehicles access to sites such as boreholes or other facilities;
and minor, short-term, associated soil erosion if works are undertaken in high rainfall periods.

101. Most of these disturbances will be on existing sites and only temporary. It is possible that
new sites will be required particularly for new bores, storage and associated facilities. Sites will
be  selected  after  community  consultation  and,  wherever  possible,  will  be  on  public  or
government-owned  land.  They  will  have  an  areal  impact  generally  limited  to  less  than  100
square  meters.  As  most  works  will  involve  the  repair  or  replacement  of  existing  pipelines  and
other  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities,  environmental  effects  will  be  insignificant.  Other
works  of  significance  include  the  proposed  repair  and  rehabilitation  and/or  construction  of
WS&S  related  structures  such  as  intakes,  pump  stations,  treatment  plants,  generator  rooms,
storage  tanks,  and  boreholes.  These  works  will  generally  be  carried  out  on  sites  of  existing
(damaged)  structures  and  no  significant  environmental  effects  are  foreseen  other  than  normal
small  building  construction  activities  such  as  cartage  of  building  materials  and  construction
noise. Again any effects will be small and temporary, possibly lasting from a few days to a few
weeks.  Specific  measures  will  be  incorporated  in  contracts  for  works  at  or  adjacent  to  water
intakes to prevent contamination of water supplies.

102. A  potential  significant  adverse  operational  impact  is  the  increased  local  discharge  of
wastewater because of improved water supplies. In many instances, wastewater discharges will
be  reduced  because  uncontrolled  connections  will  be  reduced  and  major  pipe  leaks  repaired.
Any  adverse  impact  will  be  mitigated  by  repairing  and  rehabilitating  drainage  systems  in
problem areas. Any other potential or identified adverse effects will be preempted or minimized
by  (i)  improving  water  resource  management,  and  (ii)  promoting  environmental  conservation
through community participation and education activities. The capacity of existing final disposal
sites will be considered for studies related to additional waste disposal sites.

103. Some  project  activities  will  significantly  enhance  the  environment.  The  drainage,  solid
waste management, and septage collection and treatment will substantially improve the urban
environment, particularly in Dili, through reduced flooding, improved water quality, and reduced
health risks.

104.
The  Project  will  also  contribute  environmentally  sustainable  development  through
environmental monitoring under the guidance of the PMU. Monitoring will include (i) measuring
the effectiveness of any environmental improvements needed, (ii) identifying problems that may
arise  during  the  works,  and  (iii)  if  necessary,  providing  ecological  audit  information  for  future

 21

works of this nature. The proposed monitoring will be designed to quantify the benefits gained
and  any  impacts  sustained  from  repairing  and  rehabilitating  town  and  community  WS&S
systems. The PMU  will  define environmental parameters to be monitored, and will include the
quality  of  raw  water,  treated  water,  and  delivered  water;  the  need  for  and  effectiveness  of
drainage systems; environmental conditions in river and spring catchments, including pollution
and  land  clearing,  landslide,  and  erosion  problems  affecting  WS&S  facilities;  efficiency  and
effectiveness of sanitation facilities; and growth of algae in reservoirs. WSS will be responsible
for  all  water  quality  testing  (chemical  and  bacteriological)  and,  in  cooperation  with  local
communities, also for monitoring construction and postconstruction environmental aspects.

105. An  environmental  specialist  under  the  Project  will  assist  the  PMU  in  ensuring  that
appropriate  environmental  mitigation  measures  are  included  in  implementing  project  activities
and that the PMU implements appropriate monitoring and reporting.

106.
Thus, while there will be some minor and transient environmental impacts, the medium-
and long-term impacts of the Project are positive, especially in promoting economic and social
development  in  East  Timor  and  facilitating  the  nation's  reconstruction  and  development.  A
detailed  environmental  impact  assessment  is  not  required.  However,  if  any  new  additional

compile project environmental reports, information from which will be passed on to the relevant

employment for local labor, thus helping to create a stable social and economic environment.

110. Under  the  Project,  a  series  of  participatory  exercises  at  community,  local,  district,  and
regional  levels  with  citizens,  government,  and  civil  society  (and  the  private  sector  as  relevant)
will  be  led  by  a  participation  specialist  working  with  a  small  team.  The  exercises  will  permit
assessment of progress and challenges in the ongoing WSSRP-1 and promote improvements in
the Project. Voices of poor and vulnerable citizens will be heard in planning subsequent steps,
and  the  work  of  government  and  civil  society  in  responding  to  these  voices  will  be  reviewed.
Citizens,  NGOs,  and  new  government  organizations  will  take  part  in  (i)  planning  sustainable
water and sanitation systems including local maintenance and management wherever feasible,
and (ii) identifying and prioritizing needs for upgrading the skills of NGO and government staff to
maximize  institutional  capacity  enhancement  and  sustainability.  Plans  for  self-monitoring  and
ongoing sharing among groups will be made in conjunction with follow-up training and support
at every level throughout the Project.

 22

The  Project  will  involve  no  relocation  or  resettlement.  Land  acquisition  will  be  minimal,
111.
with  the  majority  of  facilities  being  constructed  on  public  land  or  rights-of-way.  Procedures
established  during  WSSRP-1  will  be  used  for  negotiating  land  use  and  access  rights,  and
appropriate  compensation  for  private  land  where  public  land  is  not  available.  The  beneficiary
consultations during WSSRP-1 confirmed widespread support for the proposed activities, which
will  be  continued  in  the  Project.  The  project  construction  activities  will  generate  significant
employment  opportunities,  and  delivered  services  will  free  the  labor  force  for  more  productive
uses.

112. Even before the 1999 destruction and displacement, East Timor was one of the poorest
areas in Southeast Asia. Based on Indonesian statistics, social indicators prior to the upheaval
already  demonstrated  a  low  level  of  human  development,  with  some  50  percent  of  the
population  clustered  around  the  poverty  line.  The  situation  has  worsened  dramatically  since
September 1999.

113. ADB’s core development tenet is to combat poverty. Its commitment in East Timor is to
provide well-coordinated action to support reconstruction and long-term development planning,
as well as humanitarian relief. This is being done by, among others, working to reduce poverty,
with  particular  attention  to  ensuring  quality  basic  service  delivery,  opportunities  for  productive
sector development, and provision of associated infrastructure needs.

114. Prior  to  the  upheaval,  less  than  half  of  the  population  had  access  to  safe  water  and
sanitation  facilities.  Insufficient  water  constrained  sanitation  practices,  which  were  often
nonhygienic. Lack of sanitation facilities caused major health hazards in poorer rural and urban
areas.  Poor  households  were  further  disadvantaged  by  having  limited  access  to  basic  health
and  education  services.  With  almost  the  entire  East  Timor  population  suffering  from  the
destruction,  the  need  for  repair  and  rehabilitation  of  water  supplies  and  sanitation  facilities  is
now even higher.

115.
The Project directly addresses and seeks to overcome a number of factors that directly,
or  indirectly,  contribute  to  poverty.  WSSRP-1  was  designed  to  distribute  its  benefits  in  an
equitable manner across East Timorese urban and rural communities and the Project provides
increased  emphasis  on  community  WS&S  in  subdistrict  and  rural  areas.  The  Project  will  be
responsive to communities’ needs, contribute to sustainable and participatory development and
operation  in  the  WS&S  sector,  reduce  poverty,  and  minimize  environmental  impacts.  It  will
target communities where the need is greatest and where poorer people live (rural villages and
peri-urban  areas).  It  will  consider  the  different  needs  of  men  and  women  and  of  the  old  and
young. Where applicable, it will adopt approaches to WS&S that counteract the problems faced
by poor households in respect of service charges. In all areas, rehabilitation and improvement of
water supplies will free labor (both men and women) for more productive uses, thereby assisting
in  the  fight  against  poverty.  Improved  sanitation  facilities  and  practices,  and  the  provision  of
clean water will have beneficial health effects, particularly on children and infants, and reduce
the costs associated with disease and morbidity. This effect will particularly benefit the poor for
whom the costs of illness can be devastating.

Water Resource Management

34.
Institutional structures and systems for water supply no longer exist. Any water resource
records  were  probably  either  removed  or  destroyed  during  the  Indonesian  withdrawal.  It  is
unlikely  that  physical  assets  such  as  stream  gauging  stations  were  damaged,  although  it  is
extremely likely that many of them are no longer in operating condition.

The  greatest  potential  impact8  on  water  resources  since  the  pre-independence
35.
withdrawal  is  deforestation  of  catchment  areas,  in  particular  those  around  Dili  and  the  larger
towns.  Kerosene  stoves  were  very  common  during  the  pre-independence  administration,  and
kerosene fuel was subsidized as one of the basic family needs along with rice, cooking oil, flour,
and salt. With the stoves reportedly removed or destroyed, the remaining population have been
forced  to  rely  heavily  on  firewood.  Kerosene  is  now  far  more  expensive,  and  even  if  it  were
affordable,  the  majority  of  the  population  still  cannot  afford  to  replace  stoves.  Widespread
unemployment  has  forced  many  people  to  rely  on  firewood  collection  as  a  source  of  income.
Traditionally, firewood collectors only took branches from trees which would recover during the
following wet season (eucalyptus mainly), but the "new" collectors are cutting down all types of
trees  to  maximize  the  amount  of  firewood  collected.  Reforestation  has  commenced  in  a  small
way, and some project funding is being provided to assist in propagating seedlings and run an
information-education-communication  campaign  about  deforestation  and  its  impacts.  Some
funding is reportedly available for disseminating designs for fuel-efficient woodstoves to reduce
the rate of consumption of firewood.

Description of the Environment

1.

Physical Environment

8.
Timor is the largest and easternmost island in the Lesser Sunda Archipelago. East Timor
comprises the eastern half of Timor Island. East Timor has a contiguous area of 19,000 square
kilometers  (km2),  and  an  additional  2,461  km2  in  the  Oecusse-Ambino  enclave  inside  West
Timor.

 67

Appendix 9, page 3

The island is along the junction of the Australian and the Asian geological plates and is
9.
thus  subject  to  frequent  earthquakes.  The  rock  formations  are  primarily  sedimentary  karst
uplifted by the collision of the two plates. As the formation is recent, the karst is highly fractured
and crumbles easily. Metamorphic rock from past volcanic activity is limited to the northern and
central sections of the island. The high erosion rate from the crumbling karst layers has resulted
in the formation of alluvial plains and isolated fertile valleys.

10.
The main geographic feature is the mountain range that runs east-west along the center
of the island and that causes watercourses to flow either north to the Banda Sea or south to the
Timor Sea. Mountain peaks reach up to 3,000 meters in elevation, so watercourses are steep,
fast flowing, and, because of the extended dry season, generally ephemeral. The river systems
are short, cutting deep ravines into the unstable rock, forming deep canyons in the highlands,
and  abruptly  widening  as  they  reach  the  flat  alluvial  plains.  Often  the  rivers  narrow  as  they
approach the sea because of obstruction caused by sandbars and intertidal deposits. Countless
littoral terraces of coral origin and some extensive plateaus, also of coral origin, characterize the
north  side  of  the  island  (e.g.,  Baucau  and  Laga).  A  few  alluvial  areas  occur  between  Lautem
and  Baucau  and  in  Manatuto  District.  The  main  plains  to  the  north  occur  at  Batugade,  Lois
stream, Dili, Manatuto, and Com. The south coast comprises a wide plain that extends from the
border  east  to  Viqueque  where  it  begins  to  narrow,  through  to  Lore  in  Lautem  District.  The
enclave  of  Oecusse-Ambino  is  also  very  mountainous  with  a  narrow  coastal  strip.  Here  all
streams  flow  to  the  north.  The  volcanic  island  of  Atauro  rises  steeply  from  the  sea  to  a
maximum elevation of 999 meters on Mount Mano Coco.

2.

Climate and Water Resources

11.
Situated in the equatorial region, Timor has basically two annual seasons (wet and dry)
influenced variously by the monsoon regime, proximity to the Australian continent, and locally by
the  orographic  effects  of  the  mountainous  topography.  The  wet  season,  which  lasts  from
November  to  May,  results  from  the  northern  monsoon.  It  is  characterized  by  thunderstorms,
high  tropical  rainfall  and  temperature,  and  concomitant  humidity.  During  the  dry  season  from
June  to  October,  winds  from  the  south  bring  little  rainfall  and  result  in  lower  temperatures.
Annual rainfall ranges from some 500 to 1,500 millimeters (mm) in the low-lying coastal areas to
over  3,000  mm  in  the  mountains.  Depending  on  location,  average  wet  season  rainfall  ranges
from  70  percent  (Kova-Lima)  to  95  percent  (Ambino)  of  annual  rainfall.  Districts  along  the
northern  coastline  (Ambino,  Liquica,  Dili,  Manatuto,  and  Baucau)  have  the  lowest  rainfall,
ranging  from  about  500  mm  in  Manatuto  to  800  mm  in  Ambino  and  Baucau,  with  over  90
percent generally falling in the wet season.

12.
The  hydrological  regime  depends  primarily  on  the  climatic  conditions  of  the  alternating

short  length,  steep  gradient,  short  flood  peaks,  very  high  sediment  load,  and  mobile  beds.  In

changes  in  river  channels.  Sediments  tend  to  be  very  coarse,  with  boulders  and  large  gravel.
The mountainous topography and streamflow pattern makes the construction of dams and weirs
problematic.

Because of the relatively high rainfall and abundant springs and surface water, and the
small  population,  there  was  no  need  for  significant  groundwater  investigation  in  the  past.
Knowledge of groundwater occurrence and quality is therefore limited. Groundwater is accessed
in the mountain areas mainly through springs, which are commonly tapped at their source with
water  fed  by  gravity  to  towns  and  villages  through  small-diameter  pipelines,  often  many

from  sustaining  management  and  operations,  tariffs  also  encourage  users  to  utilize  a  resource
more effectively, further increasing the sustainability of the water resource itself.

e.

Willingness and Ability to Pay

25.
An essential component of cost recovery is the community’s willingness and ability to pay
or to participate in management. Without regard for these two issues, sustainability through cost
recovery  cannot  be  achieved.  During  project  implementation,  assessing  affordability  and
willingness to pay through a survey is suggested as basis for the progressive introduction of cost
recovery objectives. As the economy progresses, the situation will change (in varying degrees)
and WSS will need to monitor these changes to ensure the threshold is not breached.

f.

Appropriate Technology

The  importance  of  appropriate  technology  in  sustainability  cannot  be  overemphasized.
26.
Problems have been encountered with O&M in some of the emergency systems implemented by
the  United  Nations  Transitional  Administration  in  East  Timor  (UNTAET)  and  NGOs.  By
incorporating  technology  that  is  within  the  financial  capabilities  and  technical  capacities  of  the
community to manage, the extent to which the system will be sustainable will increase. Problems
relating to the lack of spare parts and repairs are also key concerns in the transfer of technology
to  rural  communities.  Within  any  program,  provision  must  be  included  to  train  community
members in the O&M of the facilities installed. In deciding appropriate technology mechanisms,
the  accessibility  of  spare  parts  must  be  considered.  In  relation  to  O&M,  encouraging  the
community  to  establish  financial  capabilities  to  sustain  ongoing  maintenance  and  repairs  must
also be considered. Appropriate technology also means use of the most cost-effective technical
solutions.

4.

Urban and Rural Groups

27.
Following the destruction, there has been a fear that rural groups will relocate to urban
areas.  There  is  no  conclusive  evidence  to  support  this  now.  Conversely,  with  the  cessation  of
Indonesian  rule  (and  their  relocation  policies),  both  urban  and  rural  populations  are  grappling
with  land  title  and  occupation  issues  that  impact  on  their  ability  to  recover  from  the  crisis.  In
some  cases,  original  landowners  are  reportedly  asking  families  to  relocate  to  their  traditional
homelands,  or  to  seek  opportunities  in  urban  areas.  Additionally,  town  and  district  borders  are
being  redrawn,  families  are  still  returning,  and  there  are  sporadic  militia  activities  within  border
districts.  Overall,  there  is  a  sense  of  change  that  is  still  affecting  people’s  decisions  and
practices, and will do so until some normality returns.

28.
It is therefore important that all programs for urban and rural areas be seen as equitable.
Urban  works  will  eventually  need  to  show  cost  recovery  because  of  the  greater  investment

 77

Appendix 10, page 6

required.  This  cost  should  not  be  borne,  even  indirectly,  by  the  rural  population.  Community
water  supplies  may  never  be  wholly  economical;  however,  their  small  investment  costs,
combined  with  linkage  to  other  community  development  objectives  (such  as  self  management,
empowerment, and community autonomy), may obviate the need for cost recovery. Additionally,
with  the  relocation  of  some  families  into  urban  areas,  and  the  development  of  improved  water
and  sanitation  facilities  in  all  communities,  it  is  imperative  that  households'  knowledge  of
appropriate water and hygienic practices be strengthened, so as to avert wastage and misuse,
and maximize health benefits.

5.

Nongovernment Organizations

29.
Over 150 international and local NGOs currently operate in East Timor. With their greater
finances and support, the international NGOs, while doing great work and often working closely
with local NGOs, are overshadowing the local organizations. On many occasions, local groups
stated  that  they  wanted  to  have  more  involvement  and  autonomy  within  the  sector.  Indeed,  a
more dynamic and larger group of local NGOs would be an asset to the sector, and the WS&S

30.
Implementation  of  WSSRP-1  used  international  and  local  NGOs  to  provide  a  range  of
services.  Further  engagement  of  NGOs  is  proposed  for  the  Project.  The  development  of  local
NGOs  and  community-based  organizations  is  significantly  encouraged  by  a  range  of  donor
programs.  The  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID)  in  particular  is
providing capacity-building support to local NGOs for WS&S activities through the NGO forum.
The intention is to build the local capacity of the East Timor NGOs to facilitate the sustainability
of community WS&S work within the country.

6.

Health

31.
Poor  health  conditions  related  to  WS&S  and  hygiene  practices  exist  widely  throughout
East Timor. While poor health in itself is a problem, high rates of morbidity adversely impact on
poor  communities.  The  increased  burden  of  caring  for  sick  family  members,  as  well  as  a
consequent  reduction  in  productive  activities,  exacerbates  the  already  poor  socioeconomic
status of the community.

7.

Minority Groups

32.
East  Timor  has  no  identified  minority  groups.  Rural  communities  are  the  main
beneficiaries  of  the  water  and  sanitation  works,  especially  those  in  the  border  districts  that
suffered  and  continue  to  suffer  the  most  interruption  to  normal  activity.  The  Project  aims  to
ensure equity across districts, between genders, and between urban and rural communities.

8.

Resettlement and Land Acquisition

The Project is not expected to require any resettlement based on existing service levels.
33.
Within urban communities, there may be some land tenure and land acquisition issues that may
require  careful  attention.  Mechanisms  for  dealing  with  land  access  issues  were  established
during  WSSRP-1  and  will  be  used  for  the  Project  if  required.  Where  public  land  was  not
available,  rights  of  access  and  use  for  a  period  of  (say)  50  years  were  negotiated  with  land
owners.

9.

Stakeholder Participation

34.
The  Project  framework  was  developed  using  a  rapid  consultative  approach  consulting
with  key  stakeholders  particularly  within  the  UNTAET  administration.  The  Project  design  is
flexible,  and  it  will  be  necessary  to  undertake  further  consultation  with  diverse  stakeholders  to
further refine the detailed activities to be implemented. A process of community participation will
be part of the detailed planning and implementation of various project activities, managed either
through  the  project  management  unit  or  through  the  participating  NGOs.  As  part  of  the
preparation for WSSRP-1, many men and women, and various community and political groups
at  national,  district,  and  community  levels  were  consulted.  Communities  and  both  formal  and
informal women’s groups were consulted extensively throughout the field visits.

It is essential that communities, local NGOs, and women’s groups be involved in project

community focus in all the water and sanitation implementation components.
